sen.j: 誰に問われるでもなく自分の人生を語るという自伝形式で、後深草天皇に仕えた女房二条の14歳（1271年）から49歳（1306年）ごろまでの境遇を書いた。
sen.e: Telling her story though asked by no one, it is written in an autobiographical style, recounting the life of Lady Nijo, Emperor Gofukakusa's lady-in-waiting, from the age of 14 (1271) to around 49 (1306); it records her relationships with the Cloistered Emperor Gofukakusa and other lovers, ceremonies at court, and the travels she made after becoming a nun.

Although no one requested it ('Towazugatari' literally means "a tale nobody asked for"), Lady Nijo wrote her autobiographical tale as she served as Emperor Gofukakusa's lady-in-waiting from the age of 14 (1271) to around 49 (1306). It records her relationships with the Cloistered (retired) Emperor Gofukakusa and other lovers, ceremonies at court, and her travels after becoming a nun.
sen.cmt: "Telling her story though asked by no one" = "Although no one requested it". Added literal translation of Towazugatari to make it a little clearer. I thought with "autobiographical tale", "recounting the life" became redundant so I cut it. Changed "the travels she made" to "her travels" to be more succinct. I also added the meaning of "cloistered" as I don't think many native speakers will be aware of the term.

sen.j: また、『とはずがたり』発見以前には後深草天皇の女性関係に関する記録が乏しく、『増鏡』における同天皇の女性関係の記述を創作あるいは弟の亀山天皇のものとの誤認説を唱える学者もいたが、この書の発見以後『増鏡』の記述に根拠がある事が確認された。
sen.e: Also, because there were very few records of Emperor Gofukakusa's romances before "The Confessions of Lady Nijo" was found, some scholars used to think that the descriptions of his romances in "The Clear Mirror" were fictional or had been confused with those of his brother Emperor Kameyama, but after the discovery of 'The Confessions of Nijo', it was confirmed that there was a basis for the descriptions in "The Clear Mirror".

Also, because there were very few records of Emperor Gofukakusa's romances before 'Towazugatari' was found, some scholars used to think that the descriptions of his romances in 'Masukagami' were fictional or had been confused with those of his brother Emperor Kameyama, but after the discovery of 'Towazugatari', it was confirmed that there was a basis for the descriptions in 'Masukagami'.
